questions.question:
Question 1: A mother reports to the OPD with the complaint that her child smells funny. On examination, 
you notice that the child has a global developmental delay and smells mousy. What is your 
probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Mousy odor is characteristically seen in phenylketonuria due to excess phenylacetate (phenyl 
ketone) formed in the body. In the absence of phenylalanine hydroxylase, phenylalanine enters into alternate metabolic 
pathways which result in the formation of phenyl lactate, phenylacetate, and 
phenylacetylglutamine.

questions.question:
Question 2: A boy who attends school is sent to the principal's office as he often distracts others by 
rhythmically rocking back and forth on his seat. His mother worried about his behavior 
brings him to you. She also gives you a history of seizures. On examination, you notice he has 
blonde hair, fair skin, microcephaly, prominent maxillae with widely spaced teeth, and 
growth retardation. His urine changes its color transiently to blue-green on the addition of 
1ml ferric chloride solution. What is the cause of CNS symptoms in this child?
questions.explanation:
The clinical vignette describes a case of phenylketonuria. CNS damage in patients with 
phenylketonuria (PKU) is caused by hyperphenylalaninemia in brain tissue. High blood levels of phenylalanine saturate the transport system across the blood-brain barrier 
causing inhibition of the cerebral uptake of other large neutral amino acids such as tyrosine and 
tryptophan impairing brain protein synthesis. Microcephaly, prominent maxillae with widely spaced teeth, enamel hypoplasia, and growth 
retardation are other common findings in untreated children. Low bone mineral density and 
osteopenia have been reported in affected individuals of all ages. Excess phenylalanine is metabolized to phenyl ketones (phenylpyruvate and phenylacetate) that 
are excreted in the urine. However, these metabolites have no role in the pathogenesis of CNS 
damage; their presence in body fluids simply signifies the severity of the condition. 247 
Sold by @itachibot Hypotyrosinemia can be partially responsible for the signs and symptoms but the primary cause is 
hyperphenylalaninemia. Laboratory diagnoses of phenylketonuria include: • Guthrie's test: growth of bacillus subtilis is seen • Ferric chloride urine test: transient blue-green color • Blood phenylalanine levels: elevated • Enzyme studies • Genetic mutation studies • Tandem mass spectrometry: Gold standard screening method for all metabolic disorders.

questions.question:
Question 3: An infant with severe vomiting who was misdiagnosed as a case of hypertrophic pyloric 
stenosis is being screened for metabolic disorders. Screening reveals hyperphenylalaninemia. 
On ordering an enzyme study, you would include all of the following enzymes except:
questions.explanation:
Defects of either phenylalanine hydroxylase (PAH) or tetrahydrobiopterin(BH4) can cause 
hyperphenylalaninemias. PAH deficiency is diagnosed as phenylketonuria. Malignant hyperphenylalaninemias include three enzyme defects, dihydropteridine 
reductase,pyruvoyl tetrahydropterin synthase, and GTP cyclohydrolase which help in BH4 
synthesis. The deficiency of BH4 impairs three hydroxylase(phenylalanine, tyrosine, and 
tryptophan), and severe neurological symptoms develop because of the lack of neurotransmitters. Dihydropteroate synthase is present only in bacteria and this makes it a useful target for 
sulfonamide antibiotics, which compete with the PABA precursor.

questions.question:
Question 4: As a physician treating a 2-month-old baby with phenylketonuria what will be your mainstay 
of treatment?
questions.explanation:
A low-phenylalanine diet is the mainstay of treatment of PKU. The goal of therapy is to reduce phenylalanine levels in the plasma and brain. Because 
phenylalanine is not synthesized endogenously, small amounts of phenylalanine should be added 
to the diet to prevent phenylalanine deficiency. Dietary deficiency of this amino acid is manifested 
by lethargy, failure to thrive, anorexia, anemia, rashes, diarrhea, and even death; moreover, 
tyrosine becomes an essential amino acid in this disorder and its adequate intake must be 
ensured. Sapropterin dihydrochloride , a synthetic form of BH4, which acts as a cofactor in patients with 
residual PAH activity, is approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) to reduce 
phenylalanine levels in PKU.

questions.question:
Question 5: An infant born out of a second-degree consanguineous marriage presents with jaundice, 
irritability, and vomiting. His mother gives a history of fever for the past 4 days. On 
examination, petechiae are present, he has hepatomegaly and extensor hypertonia of the neck 
and trunk. Labs reveal elevated serum transaminases, hypophosphatemia, and elevated levels 
of succinylacetone in serum and urine. Which of the following enzymes is deficient?
questions.explanation:
248 
Sold by @itachibot The clinical vignette describes a case of Hereditary tyrosinemia type 1 is caused by the deficiency 
of fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase (FAAH). Elevated levels of succinylacetone in serum and urine are diagnostic for tyrosinemia type I. Liver(jaundice, acute hepatic crisis, elevated serum transaminases), kidney(hypophosphatemia), 
and nerve damage(extensor hypertonia of neck and trunk) are caused by metabolites of tyrosine 
degradation, especially fumarylacetoacetate and succinylacetone, and is usually precipitated by 
minor infections. A diet low in phenylalanine and tyrosine can slow but does not halt the progression of the 
condition. The treatment of choice is nitisinone (NTBC), which inhibits 4-HPPD and reduces the 
flux of tyrosine metabolites to FAH, thus decreasing the production of the offending compounds, 
fumarylacetoacetate, and succinylacetone.

questions.question:
Question 6: A father while changing his child's diaper observes a boiled cabbage odor emanating from it. 
Curious about the smell, he calls you. As a pediatrician, you investigate the child thoroughly 
and conclude that the child is suffering from Type 1 Tyrosinemia. As the child grows all of the 
following complications can occur except:
questions.explanation:
Corneal ulceration is not a feature of hereditary tyrosinemia type 1. In fact, ocular manifestations 
are a feature of hereditary tyrosinemia type 2 which presumably occur due to tyrosine deposition. Boiled cabbage odor may be present in tyrosinemia resulting from increased methionine 
metabolites (sulfur-containing compounds). Features of hereditary tyrosinemia type 1 (hepatorenal tyrosinemia): • An acute hepatic crisis commonly heralds the onset of disease, which may progress to liver 
failure, hepatocellular carcinoma, and death. • Episodes of acute peripheral neuropathy resembling porphyrias often triggered by a minor 
infection, such crisis can be associated with paralytic ileus • Renal involvement, which is manifested as a Fanconi-like syndrome with hyperphosphaturia, 
hypophosphatemia, normal anion gap metabolic acidosis, and vitamin D–resistant rickets 249 
Sold by @itachibot The treatment of choice for HT Type 1 is nitisinone, which blocks early steps in the tyrosine 
degradation pathway and limits the formation of toxic tyrosine metabolites. Note: Boiled cabbage odor can also be found in cases of Hypermethioninemia.

questions.question:
Question 7: 239 
Sold by @itachibot A 2-year-old girl presented with photophobia and speech delay. On examination, she had 
bilateral herpetiform corneal ulcers and painful hyperkeratotic plaques on the palms and 
soles. Which among the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Palmar and plantar hyperkeratosis, herpetiform corneal ulcers, and intellectual disability are seen 
in hereditary tyrosinemia type 2 (Richner–Hanhart syndrome/ oculocutaneous tyrosinemia) Treatment with a diet low in tyrosine and phenylalanine aiming to achieve plasma tyrosine levels 
<500 µmol/L improves skin and eye manifestations. The image below shows herpetiform corneal ulcer:

questions.question:
Question 8: A child who was being evaluated for hypertyrosinemia is diagnosed with Richner-Hanhart 
syndrome. Which of the following enzyme deficiencies is the likely cause of hypertyrosinemia 
in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Oculocutaneous tyrosinemia/Richner-Hanhart syndrome (type II) is caused by the deficiency of 
tyrosine aminotransferase. It is a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by palmar and plantar hyperkeratosis, 
herpetiform corneal ulcers, and intellectual disability.Untreated patients have 
marked hypertyrosinemia. In contrast to tyrosinemia type I, liver and kidney function are normal, 
as are serum concentrations of other amino acids and succinylacetone. 250 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 9: A 15-month-old baby who presented with seizures and self-injurious behavior has increased 
plasma tyrosine levels. Urine metabolic screening reveals the presence of 
4-hydroxyphenylpyruvic acid and its metabolites 4-hydroxyphenyllactic and 4-hydroxyphenyl 
acetic acids. Which of the following in-born errors of metabolism is the child suffering from?
questions.explanation:
Primary deficiency of 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvate dioxygenase (4-HPPD) causes hereditary 
tyrosinemia type 3. The diagnosis is suspected in children with sustained moderate increases in 
plasma levels of tyrosine (typically 350-700 µmol/L on a normal diet) and the presence of 
4-hydroxyphenylpyruvic acid and its metabolites 4-hydroxyphenyllactic and 
4-hydroxyphenylacetic acids in urine. Asymptomatic infants with 4-HPPD deficiency have been identified by neonatal screening for 
hypertyrosinemia. In symptomatic patients, developmental delay, seizures, intermittent ataxia, 
and self-injurious behavior have been reported. Liver and renal abnormalities are absent. Note: Transient tyrosinemia of the newborn is the most common acquired cause for increased plasma 
tyrosine levels. Seen in premature infants receiving a high protein diet and due to the immaturity 
of 4-HPPD enzyme. Mostly asymptomatic, but sometimes manifested by lethargy, poor feeding, 
and decreased motor activity. Hypertyrosinemia usually resolves spontaneously in the first 2 months of life. Treatment includes a low protein diet and vitamin C. 251 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 10: A 4-month-old infant who was started on a high-protein diet after weaning from 
breastfeeding developed severe metabolic acidosis, ketosis, failure to thrive, mild 
hepatomegaly, and an unusual swimming pool odor. A history of similar illness was noticed 
in his siblings and his father. What is the likely diagnosis? 240 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The clinical vignette and the characteristic swimming pool odor describe Hawkinsinuria. Hawkinsinuria is an autosomal-dominant condition caused by mutations in the gene for 4-HPPD. In infants, this disease causes severe metabolic acidosis, ketosis, failure to thrive, mild 
hepatomegaly, and swimming pool odor. Mental development is usually normal. Affected 
individuals excrete hawkinsin (4-hydroxyphenylpyruvic acid), and its metabolites. Treatment consists of a low-protein diet during infancy. Breastfeeding is encouraged. A trial with 
large doses of vitamin C (up to 1,000 mg/24 hour) is also recommended.

questions.question: Question 11: The following findings in an 18-year-old are characterized by a deficiency of
questions.explanation:
The following condition is characterized by the deficiency of homogentisic acid oxidase. The image represents ochronosis: Bluish-black pigmentation of the ear cartilage and/or sclera due 
to deposits of accumulated homogentisic acid. This is characteristically seen in alkaptonuria. It is a rare autosomal-recessive disorder is caused 
by the deficiency of homogentisic acid oxidase. Large amounts of homogentisic acid are formed, 
which are excreted in urine or deposited in tissues. Clinical manifestations of alkaptonuria consist 
of ochronosis and arthritis in adulthood. Arthritis predominantly involves the spine, hip, and 
knee. Radiologically, it is characterized by intervertebral calcifications. In children, blackening of 
the urine on standing is observed; it is caused by the oxidation and polymerization of 
homogentisic acid. 252 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 12: A patient presented to the OPD with complaints of pigmentation of the face and severe 
backache and stiffness. The X-Ray image of the spine is as shown. Her urine color changes to 
brownish-black on standing. Which of the following drugs can be used in her treatment? 241 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The clinical image shows the accumulation of alkapton bodies in connective tissues on the face 
and urine turning brownish-black on standing are associated 
with alkaptonuria. X-ray shows calcification of intervertebral discs called ochronotic 
spondyloarthropathy also seen in alkaptonuria. Nitisinone can be used in the treatment of 
alkaptonuria. Nitisinone, formerly known as NTBC, inhibits 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvate dioxygenase (HPPD) 
(early step in the tyrosine degradation pathway) and efficiently reduces homogentisic acid 
production in alkaptonuria. Treatment of arthritis is symptomatic. In presymptomatic individuals, 
treatment using a combination of nitisinone with phenylalanine and a tyrosine restricted diet can 
be tried. The patient’s urine contains elevated levels of homogentisic acid, which is oxidized to a dark 
pigment on standing as shown below in the image:

questions.question:
Question 13: A 10-year-old boy presented with right-sided weakness and deviation of angle of mouth to the 
left is diagnosed to have a metabolic disorder. Diffusion-weighted MRI reveals diffusion 
restriction along the left middle cerebral artery. Which of the following defects can be 
responsible for the boy's condition?
questions.explanation:
The clinical vignette describes a thrombotic stroke in the left MCA territory. Elevated levels of 
serum homocysteine lead to a hypercoagulable state. Homocystinuria is caused by the following: • Cystathionine -Synthase deficiency: This is classic homocystinuria. The most common inborn 
error of methionine metabolism. • Defects in methylcobalamin formation: Methylcobalamin is the cofactor for the enzyme 
methionine synthase, which catalyzes the remethylation of homocysteine to methionine. • Deficiency of methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase: This enzyme reduces 5,10 
methylenetetrahydrofolate to form 5-methyltetrahydrofolate, which provides the methyl group 
needed for remethylation of homocysteine to methionine. 253 
Sold by @itachibot • Pyridoxine deficiency: B6 is the co-factor for the enzyme cystathionine -synthase Metabolic disorders which can cause stroke include: • Homocystinuria • MELAS (metabolic encephalopathy, lactic acidosis, and stroke-like episodes) • Leigh syndrome • Fabry's disease • Propionic acidemia • Glutaric aciduria Vitamin C deficiency increases the risk of hemorrhagic stroke.

questions.question:
Question 14: An 8-month-old boy presented with lethargy, failure to thrive, and developmental delay. On 
investigation, he had elevated levels of homocysteine in blood and homocystinuria. As the 
child grows, which of the following features is least likely to develop?
questions.explanation:
The above findings support a diagnosis of homocystinuria. Short stature is not a manifestation of 
homocystinuria. Manifestations of homocystinuria: • Ectopia lentis - downward and inward subluxation (inferonasal). • Intellectual disability and psychiatric and behavioral disorders • Thromboembolic episodes like stroke and MI • Skeletal abnormalities resembling those of Marfan syndrome: They are tall and thin, (NOT short) 
with elongated limbs and arachnodactyly.

questions.question:
Question 15: A 16-year-old boy with frequent episodes of photosensitive dermatitis, diarrhea, and 
depression is diagnosed to have a metabolic disorder. Metabolism of which of the following 
amino acids is affected?
questions.explanation:
254 
Sold by @itachibot Pellagra-like symptoms- photosensitive dermatitis, diarrhea, and episodic depression are seen in 
the deficiency of tryptophan. Niacin is not strictly a vitamin, since it can be synthesized in the body from the essential amino 
acid tryptophan; deficiency of tryptophan causes pellagra-like symptoms. Treatment with nicotinic acid or nicotinamide (50-300 mg/24 hr) and a high protein diet results 
in a favorable response in symptomatic patients with Hartnup disease. The image below shows Casal's necklace, a lesion seen around the neck which is caused due to the 
deficiency of niacin or nicotinic acid.

questions.question: Question 16: Which of the following is false regarding Hartnup disease?

options.a: Defect in the transport of monoamino-monocarboxylic amino acids, including tryptophan, is
options.b: Defect in the B0AT1 protein occurs in the intestine and renal tubules
options.c: Pellagra-like rash may develop in symptomatic patients
options.d: Treatment is with supplementation of tryptophan

questions.explanation:
The treatment of Hartnup disease is not with the supplementation of tryptophan. Hartnup disease • It is caused by a defect in the transport of monoamino-monocarboxylic (neutral) amino acids, 
including tryptophan, by the intestinal mucosa and renal tubules. • There is a defect in B0AT1 protein in the intestine/ renal tubules or both, which is caused by a 
mutation in SLC6A19. • Tryptophan is an essential amino acid and a precursor for nicotinic acid (niacin) and serotonin. 
Decreased intestinal absorption of tryptophan in conjunction with its increased renal loss causes 
reduced availability of tryptophan for niacin synthesis in affected individuals. • A pellagra-like rash may develop in symptomatic patients, and some patients may have 
intermittent ataxia. • Diagnosis is based on aminoaciduria and increased excretion of indole compounds detected 
by Obermeyer test. • Treatment is with nicotinic acid or nicotinamide and a high-protein diet. 255 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 17: An infant with poor feeding is suspected to have an inborn error of metabolism. Further 
evaluation reveals hyperammonemia +, acidosis +, ketosis +. What is the most likely 
diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
In this case, hyperammonemia +, acidosis +, ketosis +. This is seen in organic aciduria. Organic acidemias most commonly present in infancy with poor feeding, vomiting, hypotonia, 
high anion gap metabolic acidosis, hepatomegaly, seizures. Organic acid accumulation inhibits 
gluconeogenesis and inhibits the urea cycle leading to hyperammonemia. Common organic acidurias: • Methylmalonic aciduria • Propionic aciduria • Isovaleric aciduria • Maple syrup urine disease • Glutaric aciduria type I • Multiple carboxylase deficiency

questions.question:
Question 18: 243 
Sold by @itachibot A 10-day-old male infant presented with poor feeding, and recurrent generalized convulsions. 
On examination, the pediatrician notices repetitive movements of the extremities –appears to 
be boxing and bicycling and a peculiar burnt sugar odor was present in urine. What is the 
deficient enzyme in this condition?
questions.explanation:
The diagnosis is maple syrup urine disease (MSUD) which is due to deficiency of branched-chain 
-ketoacid dehydrogenase (BCKDH). Leucine, isoleucine, and valine are the 3 essential amino acids, which are branched-chain amino 
acids. Their decarboxylation is accomplished by BCKDH using thiamine (vitamin B1) 
pyrophosphate as a coenzyme. Leucine is metabolized by BCAA aminotransferase to -ketoisocaproic acid, which leads to the 
disrupted metabolism of neurotransmitters and amino acids (glutamate, GABA, glutamine, 256 
Sold by @itachibot alanine, and aspartate). -Ketoisocaproic acid can reversibly inhibit oxidative phosphorylation 
and result in cerebral lactic acidosis. Collectively, these processes are detrimental to the normal 
function of neurons and glia, clinically manifesting as encephalopathy and brain edema and 
referred to as leucinosis. Treatment options include hemodialysis, restricting dietary substances, thiamine for milder 
forms, and orthotopic liver transplant.

questions.question:
Question 19: While doing your morning rounds in the pediatrics department, you notice a peculiar rancid 
cheese odor emanating from a six-month-old girl who was admitted for respiratory distress. 
Second-degree consanguinity was documented between the parents. Urine organic acid 
analysis by gas chromatography-mass spectrometry showed marked excretion of 
3-hydroxybutyric acid along with moderate excretion of 3- hydroxy-isovaleric acid. What is 
the most likely condition is she suffering from?
questions.explanation:
The clinical vignette suggests a diagnosis of isovaleric acidemia. Sweaty-feet odor or rancid cheese 
odor may be present. Isovaleric acidemia is caused by the deficiency of the enzyme isovaleryl CoA dehydrogenase, 
which affects the breakdown pathway of leucine leading to the accumulation of intermediates.

questions.question:
Question 20: A mother brings her 3-year-old boy with the complaints that her child's urine smells like her 
tomcat's urine. She also gives a history of generalized seizures and perioral desquamating 
lesions. On examination, the child has global developmental delay and diffuse thinning of the 
scalp. Investigations reveal multiple carboxylase deficiency. What is the treatment of choice?
questions.explanation:
Biotin is the treatment of choice for multiple carboxylase deficiency. Multiple carboxylase deficiency refers to one of two inherited defects of biotin metabolism. 
Tomcat urine is characteristically seen in multiple carboxylase deficiency. • Neonatal/infantile form is caused by a deficiency of holocarboxylase synthetase and presents in 
the first week of life with lethargy, poor muscle tone, and vomiting. • Juvenile/late form is caused by biotinidase deficiency and is associated with a slow but 
progressive loss of biotin in the urine, leading to organic aciduria. It is characterized by alopecia, 
ataxia, ketoacidosis, dermatitis, seizures, myoclonus, and nystagmus. Both infantile and late-onset multiple carboxylase deficiency can be treated with pharmacological 
doses of biotin. It is called multiple carboxylase deficiency because biotin is a water-soluble vitamin that is a 
cofactor for all 4 carboxylase enzymes in humans: • Pyruvate carboxylase • Acetyl CoA carboxylase • Propionyl CoA carboxylase • 3-methylcrotonyl CoA carboxylase Note: Acquired deficiency of biotin may occur in infants receiving total parenteral nutrition without 
added biotin, in patients with prolonged use of antiepileptic drugs (phenobarbital, phenytoin, 
primidone, carbamazepine), and in children with short bowel syndrome or chronic diarrhea who 
are receiving formulas low in biotin. Excessive ingestion of raw eggs may also cause biotin 
deficiency because the protein avidin in egg white binds biotin, decreasing its absorption. Infants 
with a biotin deficiency may develop dermatitis, alopecia, and candidal skin infections. This 257 
Sold by @itachibot condition readily responds to treatment with oral biotin.

questions.question:
Question 21: 244 
Sold by @itachibot Which of the following is the most common acquired cause of increased plasma tyrosine 
levels?
questions.explanation:
Transient tyrosinemia of the newborn is the most common acquired cause for increased plasma 
tyrosine levels. Seen in premature infants receiving a high protein diet and due to the immaturity 
of 4-HPPD enzyme. Mostly asymptomatic, but sometimes manifested by lethargy, poor feeding, 
and decreased motor activity. Treatment includes low protein diet and vitamin C. Options A and B, i.e., hepatorenal tyrosinemia and oculocutaneous tyrosinemia, are hereditary 
causes of increased tyrosine levels. Option C: Tyrosine levels are normal in alkaptonuria.

questions.question:
Question 22: Richner-Hanhart syndrome is  
.
questions.explanation:
Richner–Hanhart syndrome is hereditary tyrosinemia type 2 (oculocutaneous tyrosinemia). • It is a rare autosomal-recessive disorder is caused by the deficiency of tyrosine aminotransferase. • It is characterized by ocular manifestations, skin lesions, and mild to moderate intellectual 
disability in ~50% of the patients. • It is diagnosed by an assay of plasma tyrosine concentration. • Treatment includes a diet low in tyrosine and phenylalanine.

questions.question: Question 23: In phenylketonuria, which of the following phenyl ketones is excreted in urine?
questions.explanation:
In phenylketonuria, phenylpyruvate is excreted in the urine. In phenylketonuria (PKU), excess phenylalanine in the blood is metabolized to phenyl ketones, 
namely, phenylpyruvate and phenylacetate, which are excreted in the urine, giving rise to the term 
phenylketonuria (PKU). Acetoacetate and beta-hydroxybutyrate are keto-acids but are not phenyl ketones. These are not 
excreted in phenylketonuria.

questions.question:
Question 24: A 2-month-old infant presented with abdominal distention and increased irritability for 10 
days. Physical examination showed jaundice, hepatomegaly, and a boiled cabbage odor. 
Which among the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The clinical vignette is in favor of tyrosinemia. Boiled cabbage odor may be present in tyrosinemia 
resulting from increased methionine metabolites (sulfur-containing compounds). Note: Boiled cabbage odor can also be found in cases of Hypermethioninemia. 258 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 25: A neonate born out of a second-degree consanguineous marriage is suspected to have an 
inborn error of metabolism. He can present with all of the following except:
questions.explanation:
Irritability and incessant crying are not classical features of inborn errors of metabolism (IEM). Clinical clues suggesting IEM in a neonate are: • Unexpected deterioration after a normal initial period. • Nonspecific, unexplained features such as poor feeding, lethargy, vomiting, hypotonia, failure to 
thrive, respiratory abnormalities, apnea, bradycardia, and hypothermia. • Family history of similar illnesses, unexplained sibling deaths, or progressive neurological 
disease. • Parental consanguinity: Most acutely presenting metabolic disorders are autosomal recessive.

questions.question:
Question 26: A worried mother brings her 2-year-old child with the complaints that he hasn't begun 
walking or talking. On examination, there is microcephaly, fair hair, light-colored skin, and 
blue eyes. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical manifestations point to the diagnosis of Phenylketonuria (PKU). Characteristic clinical findings in Phenylketonuria: • Mental retardation • Failure to walk or talk • Seizures • Hyperactivity • Tremor • Microcephaly • Failure to grow • Deficiency of pigmentation (fair hair, light skin color, and blue eyes) Oculocutaneous albinism (OCA) is a group of inherited disorders characterized by a reduction or 
complete lack of melanin pigment in the skin, hair, and eyes. Its symptoms are albinism with vision problems, which include: • Strabismus • Photophobia • Nystagmus • Impaired vision or blindness • Astigmatism Neuropsychiatric manifestations are not seen. 259 
Sold by @itachibot Metabolic Disorders of Urea Cycle, Complex Molecules, and Carbohydrates
